article:
'Decision-making software' (DMS) is a type of decision support system to help
individuals and organizations with their decision-making processes, typically
resulting in ranking, sorting or choosing from among alternatives.

An early example of DMS was described in 1973. Dyer, JS (1973),
"A time-sharing computer program for the solution of the multiple criteria
problem", Management Science, 19: 1379-83. Wallenius, J, Dyer, JS, Fishburn, PC, Steuer, RE, Zionts, S
and Deb, K (1992), "Multiple criteria decision making, multiattribute utility
theory: The next ten years", Management Science, 38: 645-54. Prior to the
advent of the World Wide Web, most DMS was spreadsheet-based, with the first web-based DMS appearing in the mid-
1990s. Koksalan, M, Wallenius, J, and Zionts, S,
Multiple Criteria Decision Making: From Early History to the 21st Century, World
Scientific Publishing: Singapore, 2011. Nowadays, at least 20 DMS products
(mostly web-based) are available. Weistroffer, HR,
Smith, CH, and Narula, SC, "Multiple criteria decision support software", Ch 24
in: Figueira, J, Greco, S and Ehrgott, M, eds, Multiple Criteria Decision
Analysis: State of the Art Surveys Series, Springer: New York, 2005. McGinley, P (2012), [http://www.orms-today.org/surveys/das/das.html
"Decision analysis software survey"], OR/MS Today 39.

Though DMS exists for the various stages of structuring and solving decision
problems â from brain-storming problems to representing decision-maker
preferences and reaching decisions â most DMS focuses on choosing from among a
group of alternatives characterized on multiple criteria or attributes.
